A solar eclipse occurs when the Moon passes between Earth and the Sun, thereby obscuring Earth's view of the Sun, totally or partially. Such an alignment coincides with a new moon, indicating the Moon is closest to the plane of the Earth's orbit.[1] In a total eclipse, the disk of the Sun is fully obscured by the Moon. In partial and annular eclipses, only part of the Sun is obscured.

Total solar eclipse
A total solar eclipse occurs when the Moon completely covers the Sun's disk, as seen in this 1999 solar eclipse. Solar prominences can be seen along the limb (in red) as well as extensive coronal filaments.
Annular solar eclipsePartial solar eclipse
An annular solar eclipse (left) occurs when the Moon is too far away to completely cover the Sun's disk (May 20, 2012). During a partial solar eclipse (right), the Moon blocks only part of the Sun's disk (October 23, 2014).
If the Moon were in a perfectly circular orbit and in the same orbital plane as Earth, there would be total solar eclipses every new moon. Instead, because the Moon's orbit is tilted at about 5 degrees to Earth's orbit, its shadow usually misses Earth. Solar (and lunar) eclipses therefore happen only during eclipse seasons, resulting in at least two, and up to five, solar eclipses each year, no more than two of which can be total.[2][3] Total eclipses are more rare because they require a more precise alignment between the centers of the Sun and Moon, and because the Moon's apparent size in the sky is sometimes too small to fully cover the Sun. Total solar eclipses occur rarely at a given place on Earth, on average about every 360 to 410 years.

An eclipse is a natural phenomenon. In some ancient and modern cultures, solar eclipses were attributed to supernatural causes or regarded as bad omens. Astronomers' predictions of eclipses began in China as early as the 4th century BC; eclipses hundreds of years into the future may now be predicted with high accuracy.

Looking directly at the Sun can lead to permanent eye damage, so special eye protection or indirect viewing techniques are used when viewing a solar eclipse. Only the total phase of a total solar eclipse is safe to view without protection. Enthusiasts known as eclipse chasers or umbraphiles travel to remote locations to see solar eclipses.[4][5]

Contents
Types


Partial and annular phases of the solar eclipse of May 20, 2012
There are four types of solar eclipses:

A total eclipse occurs when the dark silhouette of the Moon completely obscures the intensely bright light of the Sun, allowing the much fainter solar corona to be visible. During any one eclipse, totality occurs at best only in a narrow track on the surface of Earth.[6] This narrow track is called the path of totality.[7]
An annular eclipse occurs when the Sun and Moon are exactly in line with the Earth, but the apparent size of the Moon is smaller than that of the Sun. Hence the Sun appears as a very bright ring, or annulus, surrounding the dark disk of the Moon.[8]
A hybrid eclipse (also called annular/total eclipse) shifts between a total and annular eclipse. At certain points on the surface of Earth, it appears as a total eclipse, whereas at other points it appears as annular. Hybrid eclipses are comparatively rare.[8]
A partial eclipse occurs when the Sun and Moon are not exactly in line with the Earth and the Moon only partially obscures the Sun. This phenomenon can usually be seen from a large part of the Earth outside of the track of an annular or total eclipse. However, some eclipses can be seen only as a partial eclipse, because the umbra passes above the Earth's polar regions and never intersects the Earth's surface.[8] Partial eclipses are virtually unnoticeable in terms of the Sun's brightness, as it takes well over 90% coverage to notice any darkening at all. Even at 99%, it would be no darker than civil twilight.[9]

This took place on the very first day of my junior year of high school. I was out of the zone of totality, but I got to see the sun about half covered. It happened JUST as school let out, and conveniently I had an astronomy class that day, last period. He gave all of us eclipse glasses and we ran out to the parking lot as school let out to go see it. I was so lucky that I had that class at that particular time; I didn't even know an eclipse was scheduled to happen. I did manage to take pictures of it with my phone by zooming in as far as I could and covering the camera lens with the eclipse glasses. I ended up getting some cool crescent sun shots. For the 2024 US eclipse, I live right in the path of totality and I can't wait to see it then.

Crowd's behaviour slightly resembles one in Isaak Asimov's "Nightfall", where people were going crazy because of eclipse.

I took the family camping at Ochoco Lake (SW of Madras), to watch the eclipse. I remember how much traffic there was afterwards (hours of bumper to bumper), and from a man who absolutely hates traffic, taking the family to watch something that lasted only 3 minutes was “totally” worth it. The awe and magical experience shared with the group around us was amazing. I remember not expecting the sudden decrease in temperature as the total eclipse approached. But I was really amazed by this black hole in the sky with wispy hair like filaments of light emerging out all around the edge of the dark disk. It was one of the most memorable moments in my life and watching the video brought me back to that place. I’m looking forward to 2024.

comment_text: I lived in a perfect spot for watching the solar eclipse and I remember just before we got on the bus, they handed us eclipse glasses, then after that we got home my family just chilled in the backyard - getting ready to watch it. Tbh I wasn't the quickest kid and I was still confused about what was supposed to happen and then it started getting darker and darker, and when the full eclipse hit, everything got quiet. People in the neighborhood, birds, animals near us and probably anything else that could make a sound stopped for the entire time. It feels like a fever dream looking back on it now lol but I swear it's like the wildlife had respect for what was happening too.

I live in New England and I am so excited for the total eclipse that will happen here in 2024. It will be my first, and probably last, solar eclipse that I will see. And from where I'll be, it will be a complete total eclipse.

I live in Casper WY and saw it at our cabin at 8000’ elevation surrounded by tall lodge pole pines. Easily one of the most amazing things I’ve ever experienced! As totality approached it did get cooler and darker but I was amazed at how much light was still there with just a sliver of the sun still showing. When the diamond ring (the phenomenon of just a small ball of light on one side of the sun) left and the eclipse went total, it was like all the light just got sucked back into the moon and then “poof”, the corona just popped out at you. You could hear the collective gasps of the crowd in a meadow about 2/10ths of a mile away, then cheers broke out. Lasted for a couple of minutes then the sun popped back out. Easily one of the most amazing things I have ever experienced. You don’t “see” a total solar eclipse, you “experience” it. We had family from Chicago with us, and it was so moving we found we were mostly quiet for the rest of the day. I can see why some people travel the globe to experience them again, especially if you had already seen one.

I drove 300 miles south from Richmond at the last possible hour on a whim just because I didn't want to miss it. The weather looked good (besides being scorching hot that day) and my car was gassed up and ready. I barely made it because I didn't really know exactly where to go but when I started seeing people camping out on their lawns I knew I must be getting close. I ended up in a park behind a gas station somewhere in South Carolina, basically due east of Myrtle Beach (which I drove to directly after the eclipse and jumped in the ocean for an evening swim).  Most the people in the park had come from other places and I even met a couple from where I live. It was a totally awesome experience I'll never forget.

And we were supposed to be back in time for the eclipse, but of course missed it by like 30 minutes... 😒 I would've really been pissed if my cousin hadn't gotten us some mushrooms for the trip. The river was just outside the totality ring, and we were on the interstate on our way back home, well within the totality area, and missed it. Didn't help that he and I ate the mushrooms on the way there, so once we got in the water, we didn't make much headway. First time I'd ever been in a canoe, I'm literally twice the size of my cousin, and he decided I should be in front and let him steer. Even though, I'd actually gotten into the back of the canoe, facing the right direction, he'd got in the front, facing the wrong way. So, we rode backwards, with the heavy guy in front, facing the rear... And since, mushrooms... Took us a while to figure out this wasn't working. Then, dumped it a few times, even after we got going the right way. And I missed a perfect crane feather, propped up on a rock even with a beam of sunshine on it. Didn't see it til it was too late to get over to it, but I should've just dove in and swam. It would've been perfect to go with my eagle feather I'd just received. It was an hour in, so I figured I'd see another one. Nope. Even though we followed that damn crane for hours, not one more feather.

A total solar eclipse occurred on August 21, 2017. This total solar eclipse was a Great American Eclipse because totality was visible exclusively in the United States of America.
Totality began at North Pacific Ocean before entering Oregon and ended at North Atlantic Ocean after exiting South Carolina.
The Moon was just 3 days after perigee, making it a relatively large.

During the year 2017, there were 2 solar eclipses and 2 lunar eclipses.
* A penumbral lunar eclipse on February 11th, 4.4 days after perigee, Lunar Saros series 114, Gamma -1.02548, Penumbral magnitude 0.98838, Umbral magnitude -0.03539;
* An annular solar eclipse on February 26th, 4.7 days before perigee, Solar Saros series 140, Gamma -0.45780, Eclipse magnitude 0.99223, Eclipse obscuration 0.98451;
* A partial lunar eclipse on August 7th, 5 days after apogee, Lunar Saros series 119, Gamma 0.86690, Penumbral magnitude 1.28863, Umbral magnitude 0.24645;
* A total solar eclipse on August 21st, 3.2 days after perigee, Solar Saros series 145, Gamma 0.43671; Eclipse magnitude 1.03059, Eclipse obscuration 1.06211

we live at  a very special time. we have the  privileg, to observe  perfect  solar eclipses due  to  the equal size of  the sun and the Moon appear in the sky.  but the moon's orbit is changing.  the moon's orbit grows about 1.5 inches larger every year. As the moon's orbit takes it farther and farther away from Earth, the Moon will appear smaller and smaller in our sky. total solar eclipses  won't be around forever and haven't always been.  we  live   exactly at the right time. The only way solar eclipse occurs is as follows.
Though the moon is not a rock it causes solar eclipse, just like the clouds block the sun light.as the distance between the moon and the sun is decreasing the moon lighted portion is also decreasing(observe). when the moon is exactly under the sun the whole body of the moon will be seen dark blocking the sun light for certain/specific area on earth (in solar eclipse case....),
Also remember: full moon occurs when the distance between the sun and the moon is the maximum. Observe and prove for yourself.

In August of 2017 me, my two brothers Brad & Kevon, sister-in-law Debbie and a slew full of cousins were in the home state of our parents Keith and Vonnie. We witnessed the total eclipse of the Sun in Grand Island, Nebraska - ground zero of the eclipse.
Two years later the pictures still are a mystery but do they answer very important questions?
How did the Sun move in front of the moon after the total eclipse? A sun millions of miles and away and millions of miles in diameter could not have performed such a feat but...a sun that is at a very close orbit near the moon and near the same size as the moon most certainly did..

Eclipse, August 21, 2017
For years people knew it was coming.
The ancients feared it
But
they needn't have worried.
It's just the moon in front of the sun.
Today, people wait with eager anticipation.
Now it begins!
Slowly but surely
The black disc eats up the sun!
Some people may scream
Some may pray
Some may declare it the start of the end.
They can't stop it.
The Cosmos was wound up to run according to its own nature
Without reference or deference to Man.
But
a few minutes later
Peeking out of the edge
A spark of light!
As if the Sun says, "The moon can't defeat me.
"Neither can you who watch.
"I was here before mankind
"And will be here long after."
The moon moves on and so do the observers.
Scientists will study,
People applaud this wonder of nature
Then turn away to go back to their lives.
It changed them:
Some will ask "why" more often.
Some will say "wow" more often
And be more aware of humans' humble place in the scheme of things.
Maybe it was more than just
The moon in front of the sun.
I’m here for the Moon

“360 Degree Sunset” of the Total Solar Eclipse 2017!
Perhaps the most sublime of all YouTube videos of the experience of Totality during the Great American Eclipse of August 21, 2017, “The Serene Majesty of the Shadow of the Moon” is choreographed to Strauss’ “The Blue Danube” in homage to the 50th anniversary of the “Space Waltz” sequence in Kubrick’s “2001: A Space Odyssey.”
https://youtu.be/-QKK5RqEr5s

DJI Spark quadcopter aerial HD images from this video above Cascade, Idaho and other aerial images are also featured in perhaps the only commemorative keepsake book yet published, “MOON MISSION: Passage to Totality 2017” on Amazon.

Kudos to the St. Maries family that “wrote the book” on this sublime Eclipse Experience for all now to enjoy and to relive for themselves.

For years people knew it was coming.
The ancients feared it
But
they needn't have worried.
It's just the moon in front of the sun.
Today, people wait with eager anticipation.
Now it begins!
Slowly but surely
The black disc eats up the sun!
Some people may scream
Some may pray
Some may declare it the start of the apocalypse.
They can't stop it.
The Cosmos was wound up to run according to its own nature
Without reference or deference to Man.
But
a few minutes later
Peeking out of the edge
A spark of light!
As if the Sun says, "The moon can't defeat me.
"Neither can you who watch.
"I was here before mankind
"And will be here long after."
The moon moves on and so do the observers.
Scientists will study,
People applaud this wonder of nature
Then turn away to go back to their lives.
It changed them:
Some will ask "why" more often.
Some will say "wow" more often
And be more aware of humans' humble place in the scheme of things.
Maybe it was more than just
The moon in front of the sun.

It wasn't a big deal, it just got dark quickly. NOT! I had a good friend tell me that we had to go to totality about a year before it was going to happen, and that was how I felt about it at first, then I thought you know what, if it is cool enough to make some people travel around the world to see them, then I should at least go and watch once in my life. And then... I was totally blown away. I got goose bumps just remembering watching it as I watched this video. I now understand how awesome they are, and how important it is to be dead center on the line of totality. We were at a location that had about ten seconds less than on the center line, and I was wishing that we had just gone a little bit further to be in the center. Words cannot describe the intensity of totality, but if I can convince someone to go and watch it for themselves, then this will not be in vain. I'm definitely traveling halfway across the country to see the next one!

That part was not fun... but the trip was still totally worth it.

What amazed me was 1. how cold it got about 15 minutes before totality. I was in Wyoming when it happened and it dropped about 20 degrees within a few minutes, even though the light difference was barely perceptible and 2. how quickly it did get dark. With nearly 99% of the sun covered, it still was pretty bright. But once the last sliver of light was covered up, it got dark all of a sudden. Venus and other stars were visible. It lasted about 90 seconds and then, it's like a switch was flipped on and the light came back almost instantly. Very cool. I look forward to the next one in Dallas in 7 years.

Is anyone gonna contemplate on the stunning reality of the odds of this phenomenon?
The only PLACE in the solar system where you can see a full perfect eclipse where the moon orbiting the parent planet is just the exact right size and distance to fill the exact same area as the sun does, is on Earth.
The only TIME when this occurs, is right now, due to the fact that the moon was much closer to the Earth in the past (age of the dinosaurs for example) at which point not much of the corona would have been visible, nor any pearl-effect.
And only NOW in this exact TIME and PLACE, does Earth possess self-aware sentient beings capable of reflecting upon science, art and the nature of the universe itself.

Do you guys understand what i'm saying?
The odds of being on a planet where the moon perfectly covers the exact same size as the sun is, is astronomical on its own.
The odds of being on a planet at the exact right time when this happens in the vast timescale of the solar systems existance, is astronomical on its own.
The odds of having a sentient living technological civilization on that exact same planet in that exact same time as well, is beyond astronomically unlikely.

If any of you guys are mathematicians and understand odds.. You know what i'm talking about.
It's almost so unlikely that it borders on ridiculousness. Perhaps witnessing a perfect eclipse is a trigger for self-awareness.

I was in the path a totality between Sage Junction Idaho and Terreton Idaho... I traveled from SD to ID to meet my son whos from there, and we traveled the night before to location and basically camped out e.g. slept in the back of the pickup on the side of the road, while still groves of cars passed the highway throughout the night and leading up to the event it was crazy. I was far from being prepared for this, but tried to use my GoPro on a tripod and my cheap Fuji camera , knowing I was ill equipped  the plan was to just observe it for the most part. I did however have a pair of real nice Minox high grade 10X binoculars to view through during totality and I gotta tell you it exceeded my expectations big time, it was incredible especially the diamond ring and the view through my binos I could see the flames or the sun's prominences  to be exact knowing that they were bigger than Jupiter and the earth put to geather. As it phased out I saw the Bailey's beads through the binos, but only briefly since I didn't want to take any chance to damage my eyes, then it was back to using the safety glasses. It is something I think everyone half interested in science or spirituality should take the time to go see because it evokes a inner emotion that is hard to describe. My only complaints were it didn't last very long and the mass exodus of traffic out of there back to Pocatello was exhausting.... otherwise just the chance to see it with my son was a definitely a defining moment I'll never forget. The path of totality is the way to go or you miss what is coined a total eclipse. If you missed this one make plans to see the next one 2024  you wont regret it.

This was my first total eclipse as well, and I was trying to think of an analogy to describe what it was like to others who have never experienced totality.  So, here is what I came up with.  Most of us learned about sex as children at one time or another.  We learn who had what parts and how everything might work, etc.  And then, we grew and finally we had sex for the first time, maybe shouting "Oh my God!" a lot.  For me, that is what it was like seeing my first totality.  I know all the astronomy & physics, but "Oh my God!"  You'll notice that Derrick doesn't do a lot of descriptive narrative during totality itself, but does say "Oh, my God!" over and over again, as did I.  Note to Derrick:  I'll see you in Texas in 2024!  The path of totality hits Texas and cuts right across Lake Buchanan, a nice resort area where one can rent cabins or camp, only 150 miles from Texas A&M, College Station, TX.

manufacturer', or 'the creator', or 'the inventor', or 'the producer'.
Whatever the reply would be, it would all be similar.

Now I ask you, 'How did our universe come into existence?' A common
answer would be that initially there was a singularity point, then there
was the Big Bang, then a secondary separation which gave rise to
galaxies and eventually the sun, the moon and the earth on which we
live. Science calls this the Big Bang Theory and only came to know of
this theory recently, just a few decades ago. This is already mentioned
in the Quran over 1400 years ago in Surah Anbiya, chapter 21, verse 30,
"Have those who disbelieved not considered that the heavens and the
earth were a joined entity, and We separated them..." Who could have
known this?

If you are asked, 'Is the light of the moon its own light or reflected
light?', you would say that previously it was thought that the moon
produced its own light but recently science has discovered that the
light of the moon is not its own light but reflected light. The Qur'an
mentions over 1400 years ago in Surah Furqan, chapter 25, verse 61
"Blessed is He who has placed in the sky great stars and placed therein a
[burning] lamp and luminous moon". The Arabic word used for moonlight
in the Qur'an is "muneer" or "noor" meaning reflected light or borrowed
light. Who could have mentioned this 1400 years ago?

The world that we live on, what's the shape of this earth on which we
live? The common answer would be 'it is spherical'. When did we come to
know this for sure? The answer would be 'It was in the 16th century when
the Magellan-Elcano expedition's circumnavigation of Earth proved it to
be spherical. But the Quran tells us over 1400 years ago, in Surah
Naziat, chapter 79, verse 30, "And after that He spread the earth." The
Arabic word at the end of this verse, 'Dahahaa', one of its meanings is
'the earth as an expanse' whilst the other Arabic word which it derives
from refers to an ostrich egg. Science tells us that earth is ellipsoid
in shape and if you analyse the shape of an ostridge egg, that too is an
ellipsoid in shape. Who could have mentioned over 1400 years ago that
the shape of the earth is an ellipsoid?

Today, science tells us that the universe is expanding, which is
mentioned in the Quran over 1400 years ago in Surah Dhariyat , chapter
51, verse 47, "With power did We construct the heaven. Verily, We are
Able to extend the vastness of space thereof."

Today we have come to know about the 2 seas with different types of
water, sweet and salty, and there is a barrier between them. This is
mentioned in the Quran in Surah Furqan, chapter 25, verse 53 and Surah
Rahman Chapter 55 verse 17-18. "And it is He Who has let free the two
seas [kinds of water]: this is palatable and sweet, and that is salt and
bitter, and He has set a barrier and a complete partition between
them." "He has let loose the two seas [the salt and fresh water] meeting
together. Between them is a barrier which none of them can transgress."
Who could have known this over 1400 years ago in the Arabian desert?

Today science tells us it is the mountains that prevents the earth from
shaking which is mentioned in the Quran over 1400 years ago in Surah
Naba, chapter 78, verses 6-7.

The Quran speaks of biology that "We have created every living creature
from water", in Surah Anbiya, chapter 21, verse 30. The Quran mentions
this over 1400 years ago.

The Quran speaks of zoology, about the lifestyle of the spider in Surah
Ankaboot, chapter 29, verse 41, about the ant in Surah Naml chapter 27,
verse 17-18, about the bee in Surah Nahl, chapter 16, verse 66,68-69.

The Quran speaks of embryology in Surah Alaq, ch 96, verses 1-2. "We
have created the humans from alaqah, a leech like substance."

The Quran speaks of embryological stages in Surah Muminoon, chapter 23,
verse 12-14.


We can go on and on talking about the scientific points, there are more
than 1000 verses in the Quran which speaks about science. After all
these scientific facts, I ask you, Who could have mentioned that in the
Quran? The only reply you can give you is the creator, the manufacturer,
the inventor, the producer. This creator, this manufacturer, this
producer, this inventor, we Muslims know him as Allah, the Almighty God.

I saw one in the U.K. In 1999. It was awesome. I got hold of a piece of welders glass to view it. I wish that we had more information back then about what to look out for such as the shadow ripples just before totality etc. I would have also gone to the beach to watch the shadow rush towards us rather than a field that the local authorities had prepared. It was a nice atmosphere but absolutely packed with people. All the shops closed half an hour before totality. It was hilarious to overhear a lady in one shop fretting about whether she would manage to get people out of her pasty shop for the event! I would love to see another one. Spain will be the next nearest but I don't think I could wait until 2026. There are two things everyone should get to see if at all possible. A total eclipse and the Northern Lights. They are both awe inspiring. Thank you for sharing your experience!

Most people who suffer injury from observing a solar eclipse don’t notice any symptoms for a day or so. That’s why so many of us have been warning you not to look at the sun.

Don’t freak out though. If you only looked at the sun for a few seconds, you’re probably okay. No one’s done a careful study for obvious reasons, but the medical consensus seems to be that it might take up to 100 seconds cumulative exposure to cause permanent damage. Still, if in doubt, get to a doctor.

People asked me today: so what's it like to see a total eclipse? Imagine you had lived your whole life in the daylight. You've never seen what night looks like. Then finally, one day, you get to watch the sun go down with a perfect sunset and you see the stars come out for the first time ever. It would probably be a little scary, super weird, but you'd be struck in awe and possibly a little emotional. That's exactly the feeling of seeing a total solar eclipse.

And that feeling when it goes 100% total is why a 99% eclipse is miles away from 100%. There were so many people who thought, "eh, it's gonna be 99% here, so why bother traveling." It was so worth the trip ! Without totality, you never get the corona, you never get the 360-degree sunset, you never get the stars and planets becoming visible -- you just don't get that amazing feeling of experiencing something so surreal !! At 99%, yes, the light is dimmer, the shadows are different, there's definitely something cool going on -- but when it hits 100% it changes !! It becomes a completely different experience. You heard Derek and all the other people reacting -- it's beyond words!!

Ooooh, great footage!  I live in Missoula and I drove to Idaho Falls to see it and it was utterly amazing!  It got so cold and I was walking around in my socks and dew had settled on the grass and my socks got wet.  It blew my mind to see the 360 degrees sunsets! I was in McMinnville so we got only 55 seconds of totality but oh my god. I've never experienced anything like that. I would be okay if this was the only total eclipse i ever got to experience but by golly does it make me want to watch another, with longer totality duration and in a place I can see the horizon. There's no way to document this experience fully. It's a complete sensory experience of overwhelming proportions. It starts with the light getting weaker and sharper and wan like it's coming through a thicker and thicker filter, the lights coming through the gaps in tree leaves took on upside-down crescent shapes. It's not like the light in evening at all. The colors around got somehow more intense but muted at the same time and it was so eerie and uncanny. The birds started singing evening songs, the flowers began to close. The temperature dropped significantly and dew was forming on every still surface right before our very eyes. The air smells different, it almost tastes different, and as the light got weaker and weaker, stars and planets became visible. The sky had a glow at the horizon where the edge of the moon's shadow hit. The birds went silent, then a great roar and cheer of distant people rose into the air. And then the last drop of sunlight turned into that brilliant diamond ring, and we were in twilight. The moon covering the sun is the weirdest feeling, and the sight is incapable of reproduction on even the best cameras. The corona is like these silvery, whispy petals extending from this dark orb, and because we were on the edge of totality, right around the silhouette of the moon we could see hot pink beads of the prominences and chromosphere the whole time. I could have never imagined what it was like. But it was really amazing to think that millions of people across the country in that 70-mile wide band were feeling the exact same wonder and awe and overwhelming sense of power that we were as we witnessed the eclipse.

In astronomy, we accept the fact that naked eye viewing is often much weaker than camera views for dim objects. So, I was pleasantly surprised to see that the naked eye view of the corona was at least as good as most video images I have seen so far, presumably because the corona is so bright. Of course an HDR image will be up there somewhere, we'll have to find that one. Ultimately the experience on the ground is what makes the trip worthwhile, so panned shots of the crowd and audio are gold.

re-commenting this so that people don't have to dig through the replies of my last comment

for everyone replying, yes i know its VERY possible to see multiple eclipses in your life, but not everyone has the opportunity to see another one or travel to see more. For those in the US, if you couldnt travel to see the 1979 one and you couldn't go to Hawaii for the 1991 eclipse, this might be the only eclipse you got to see. i hope everyone that saw this year's will be able to experience this amazing event again, but many people wont be able to.

i do also agree a total solar eclipse can be stunning in eerie silence, so if really bothers you if people cheer, the best idea would be to go somewhere alone or just with your group, not to a viewing party or site. that way you'll get the most out of the eclipse. this is probably coming from those who aren't seeing their first eclipse, so all i can say is remember your first eclipse and how it made you feel. don't shut someone down who's seeing it for the first time because its such a great experience and people should be excited and happy.

lastly, we're not "cheering the moon on" like a soccer game, we're cheering because of how incredible it is that we get to be here with the people we love, experiencing the universe happening around us. totality is like nothing else. no perfect camera or any expert storyteller can even come close to describing what it feels like to be standing there under the total eclipse. and when you realize all of this, you cant help but cheer. you're cheering because you're alive and you either made it out here to see the eclipse or fate decided to put you in the path of totality. you're cheering because of how truly magnificent the universe is. you're cheering because no matter what, the world keeps going on around you and something inside of you is different when you come out of totality then when you went in. people cant help but celebrate something so amazing.

In your description you say that the moon passed in front of the sun when in fact the sun passed behind the moon from our perspective as both were traveling to the West and the shadow traveled from West to East.
 The object seen at 2:18 was probably one of the flights that were traveling with the shadow to maximize exposure time and get a view from high altitude with less atmospheric interference and deeper into the angle of shadow for greater occlusion.
 The majority of eclipses were not observed as many occurred over water or uninhabited areas like Antarctica. Or they were obscured by weather. Sometimes they were seen as just a darkening of the sky on the horizon and were thought to be a far off storm.

People in the comments are so concerned with 'Americans' reacted in this video. This is not a unique reaction found only in America. You will find the same reaction in every country, for every total eclipse. If you have not heard of the term 'the overview effect' I would highly recommend reading a bit about it. This is a radical spiritual and psychological shift in understanding, that is usually as result of viewing earth it from outer space. In one single glance astronauts, view the earth in its entirety, without borders or boundaries, without flags or racial segregation, there is only earth. Astronaut, Ron Garan said, ‘As I looked back at our Earth from orbital perspective I saw a world where natural and man-made boundaries disappeared”. Sultan Bin Salman al~Saud said “The first day or so we all pointed to our countries. The third or fourth day we were pointing to our continents. By the fifth day, we were aware of only Earth”. David Bever, co-founder of The Overview Institute said ‘We have been evolving from the beginning of civilization to a larger and larger perspective of life”. Many can experience this effect from on the ground while observing a celestial event such as a total solar eclipse. Calling a country out based on how they react to this expirence is in direct opposition to how this has made me feel today. It abruptly reformed the borders around me and I guess thats why it bothered me so.

Probably the first video of yours that I disliked. I subscribe to Veritasium to learn things. I was hoping to learn some interesting new science that we learned from the eclipse, or maybe some unexpected fact in the style of most of your videos on this channel. You've done a lot of the more personal stuff on 2veritasium, and that's where I'd expect this video. This was essentially a reaction video, and I expect better from the Veritasium channel (and, frankly, better from 2veritasium as well). I get that you're excited, but maybe showing a bunch of people being loud and some images of an eclipse (something portrayed commonly in science fiction and thus not as impactful as it is intended) isn't the best way to spread passion about science. This isn't going to be a popular opinion, and that's fine. Unpopular opinions are what drive change and made science possible.

Thank you for the video, regardless. It clearly took a lot of work. I just think that perhaps it's not the best fit for this channel's stated goals.

I saw the eclipse in 1999, no one screamed like this, people are different everywhere. I didnt like it as much as I thought I would. The atmosphere grew spooky and cold, bird were confused and it lasted several minutes until the sun regained its powerful light. "Nobody" knew what to do. It was confusing indeed to witness a kind of time lapse sunset and -rise in the middle of the day so out of sync from the usual day cycle. There is no comparison between a total eclipse and a partial, the last 1% matter a lot. In the end is was a shallow experience. It was all too fast and too unreal for me. Two hours later it was as if nothing had happened, and did it? Very strange, but worth the trip.

I live in Ontario and I thought we would be lucky to see a sliver of the eclipse and wasn't even going to bother. But about an hour before it started I built a camera obscura (a box with a screen at one end and a hole at the other) in about 15 minutes, and I so glad that I did. We ended op getting 70ish % coverage here and it was still awesome. The sky's colour changed, shadows got a  lot sharper and the light levels dropped quite a bit. I ended bringing the camera obscura around to all three of my neighbour's houses, informing them that this was happening (one had no idea) and let them view it with the camera obscura.
I believe the event was over-hyped in order do get idiotic Americans not to forget to wear the glasses.  If not, millions of people would be staring at the sun directly for hours.

I got to see totality at my University in Nebraska. My school canceled classes and held a big event on our football field. The partial eclipse portion of the event was as exciting but when totality struck, that was amazing. Just like in this video the temperature dropped dramatically and the wind was more noticeable. I didn't notice the sharpening of the shadows but that is probably because I didn't know to look for that. It is such a weird feeling to experience such darkness at noon lol. Later on I was talking to a bank worker who watched it while he was at work (they were given 2 hours off to watch it) and he said that a bunch of birds seemed to be completely confused as to what they should be doing.
For 200,000 years humans didn't know what happened and scared shitless, we are very privileged to have these knowledge and to be able to enjoy it.

How do you explain to the people who didn't experience totality, but only 98%, that they didn't experience 98% of what we did? There were 3 different events, lead up, totality, and lead out (or inverse lead up). What they saw was 98% of the lead up followed by 98% of lead out. My crew motorcycles into a remote location and after totality, we looked up maybe 1 or 2 times each just to see how it was progressing. We felt no interest in watching the lead out. However, if somehow there were repetitive cycles where we'd get to see another totality after each, we'd have spent days out there watching them. It exceeded all imagination.

Great video Derek. Until a person witnesses a total solar eclipse in person, they have no idea how incredible it is. It is beyond words. No photo or video can captures what the human eye can see of the corona. The whole thing really taps into our primal instincts. The primitive parts of our brain go a bit haywire trying to figure out how to handle what we see. You jump for joy and want to run and hide at the same time. In some ways it's as if you're watching an actual monster alien spaceship about to land on your head. It's Independence Day SciFi-ish, bit real. You're actually touched by the moon's shadow and a window to the solar system opens up right in front of your eyes. And the sun has spikes shooting out of it with a black hole where the sun's supposed to be. And then It's over. And you're never the same afterwards.
